info.name: se2349
info.description:
The **se2349** collection represents the RESTful Application Programming Interface (REST API) for NTUAFLIX. This API facilitates the management of data and services related to the NTUAFLIX platform, offering various endpoints to interact with the system. Users can utilize the API to search  
for movies, TV series, and actors, resembling the functionality of a  
comprehensive entertainment database.

request.description:
Returns a `titleObject` that contains details of the movie/series with `tconst==titleID`, as follows: | Field | Type | Description | | --- | --- | --- | | titleID | String | The identifier `tconst` | | type | String | Type of title (short, movie, tvEpisode) | | originalTitle | String | The original title | | titlePoster | String | URL of the movie/series poster | | startYear | String | The year of first airing | | endYear | String | The year of last airing (if applicable) | | genres | List | List of genres the movie/series belongs to, containing objects with the following fields:
\- `genreTitle`: String - The genre title | | titleAkas | List | List of alternative ("also known as") titles of the movie/series, containing objects with the following fields:
\- `akaTitle`: String - The alternative title
\- `regionAbbrev`: String - The region | | principals | List | List containing objects corresponding to the contributors, as follows:
\- `nameID`: String - The `nconst` field of the contributor
\- `name`: String - The `primaryName` field of the contributor
\- `category`: String - The category (director, actor, editor, etc.) of the contributor within the specific movie/episode | | rating | Object | Object with the following fields:
\- `avRating`: String - Average rating of the movie/series
\- `nVotes`: String - Number of ratings |

request.description:
Accepts a `tqueryObject` in the body as follows:

#### tqueryObject

| Field | Type | Description |
| --- | --- | --- |
| titlePart | String | Part of the title we are searching for |

Returns a list of `titleObject`s whose `originalTitle` field contains the `titlePart`.

exec: pm.test("Each titleObject matches the query criteria", function () {
// Assuming that the request was sent with a body containing the gqueryObject
// The response should be an array of titleObjects
// Check if the titleObject matches the qgenre
// Check if the titleObject has an avRating higher than or equal to minrating

request.description:
Accepts a `gqueryObject` in the body as follows:

#### gqueryObject

| Field | Type | Description |
| --- | --- | --- |
| qgenre | String | The full name of the genre we are searching for |
| minrating | String | The minimum rating |
| yrFrom | String | (Optional) Year "from" |
| yrTo | String | (Optional) Year "to" |

Returns a list of `titleObject`s where the `genres` list:  
a) Contains the `qgenre` field, and  
b) The `avRating` field has a value greater than or equal to `minrating`.

If both optional fields `yrFrom` and `yrTo` are included, the list includes only the `titleObject`s with `startYear` values satisfying `yrFrom <= startYear <= yrTo`.

request.description:
Returns a `nameObject` that contains details of the contributor with `nconst==nameID`, as follows: #### nameObject | Field | Type | Description | | --- | --- | --- | | nameID | String | The identifier `nconst` | | name | String | The full name of the contributor | | namePoster | String | URL with the image of the contributor | | birthYr | String | The year of birth | | deathYr | String | The year of death (if applicable) | | profession | String | The `primaryProfession` field | | nameTitles | List | List of movies/series where the contributor is recorded (in `title.principals`), containing objects with the following fields:
\- `titleID`: String - The identifier `tconst` of the movie/series
\- `category`: String - The category of the contributor's involvement (director, composer, actor, etc.) | This endpoint provides information about the contributor, including personal details, profession, and a list of titles in which they have participated.

request.description:
Accepts an `nqueryObject` in the body as follows:

#### nqueryObject

| Field | Type | Description |
| --- | --- | --- |
| namePart | String | Part of the contributor's name we are searching for |

Returns a list of `nameObject`s whose `name` field contains the `namePart`.

item.description:
This folder contains a collection of endpoints representing successful API calls that return relevant data. Each endpoint serves a specific purpose in interacting with the ntuaflix software. The following endpoints are implemented to fulfill necessary functionalities:

1. \[GET\] /title/:titleID:  
    Retrieve details of a movie or TV series by its unique identifier.
2. \[GET\] /searchtitle:  
    Search for titles based on a provided part of the title.
3. \[GET\] /bygenre:  
    Filter titles by genre, minimum rating, and optional release years.
4. \[GET\] /name/:nameID:  
    Retrieve details of a contributor by their unique identifier.
5. \[GET\] /searchname:  
    Search for contributors based on a provided part of their name.
    

Further insights into each endpoint are provided below for a comprehensive understanding.

item.description:
This folder provides detailed documentation on the possible error responses that can be encountered when making requests to the NTUAFLIX API. Each request is analyzed for potential issues, and the corresponding HTTP status codes are documented along with a brief description and message.

| Error Code | Description | Message |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 200 | Success | Successful call that returns a non-empty data payload |
| 204 | No data | Successful call that does not return any data (e.g., empty response) |
| 400 | Bad request | The parameters provided in the call are not valid |
| 404 | Not available | The requested service is not available |
| 500 | Internal server error | In every other case of error |

**(!) Note: Some errors are not possible in certain requests.**  
For example, the `204 No data` response, indicating a successful call that does not return any data (e.g., empty response), is not applicable to the `[GET] /title/:titleID` request. This is because when a valid `titleID` is provided, the specific title details will always be returned. In this context, it is inherently contradictory for the response to indicate a successful call without returning any data. As a result, certain errors are logically excluded in specific requests due to the expected behavior of the API.

**(!) Note: Testing error 500 is not included.**

`500 Internal server error` is typically triggered by unexpected issues on the server side. To simulate and test error 500, intentionally introduce another type of internal server error during testing. This could include scenarios such as server misconfigurations, unexpected exceptions, or other issues affecting the server's functionality.
